text: This is Unit 1 of Pimsleur's French 1. Listen to this French conversation.
Pardon, est-ce que vous comprenez l'anglais?
Non, monsieur. Je ne comprends pas l'anglais.
Je comprends un peu le français.
In the next few minutes, you'll learn not only to understand this conversation, but to take part in it yourself.
Imagine an American man sitting next to a French woman.
He wants to begin a conversation, so he says,
The French speaker is going to repeat this word part by part, starting from the end.
You are to repeat each part after him, trying to make your pronunciation sound exactly like his.
How do you say, excuse me, in French?
Now he wants to ask her if she understands English.
Now say the same word, leaving off the L sound at the beginning.
Now again with the L sound.
The difference is that when the L sound is off, you're saying English.
And when it's on, you're saying the English.
Most of the time the L sound will be there in French, even when the word the is not there in our language.
You should repeat after the speaker gives the right response, trying to make your pronunciation sound like his.
Now he wants to ask, do you understand?
Here's how to say, you understand.
Do you remember how to say, English?
And now, try to say, you understand English.
Here's the phrase that makes a question in French.
Any statement can be made into a question just by putting this in front of it.
Ask me if I understand English.
The woman answers, no. Listen and repeat.
How do you say sir or mister?
How would you ask someone if he understands?
Try to say, I understand English.
Listen to the words, I understand and you understand together.
Listen to the words, I understand and you understand together.
Ask the woman, do you understand English.
There are lots of little sounds like that.
That almost get thrown away in rapid speech.
It's important to notice them however.
Because they can often change the meaning of a sentence.
Ask me if I understand English.
Ask me if I understand English.
Now here's the name of the French language.
Say French, meaning the French language.
Listen carefully to that response again.
And notice how the L sound of "le français" almost gets lost but not quite.
Listen again, noticing how the L sound gets tacked on to the word before.
Now you try repeating it after the speaker part by part.
Now tell me that you don't understand French.
Now tell me that you don't understand French.
Je ne comprends pas le français.
Ask me if I understand French.
Est-ce que vous comprenez le français?
Est-ce que vous comprenez le français?
Here is how to say a little.
Je comprends un peu le français.
Je comprends un peu le français.
Tell me that you understand French a little.
Je comprends un peu le français.
Je comprends un peu le français.
Now the woman wants to ask him,
Listen and repeat the word American.
And now try to ask, are you American?
Est-ce que vous comprenez le français?
Here's how to say, yes, listen and repeat.
Say, I understand French a little.
Je comprends un peu le français.
Je comprends un peu le français.
Now sit back and listen to a French conversation, the same one you heard at the beginning of this tape just a few minutes ago.
Pardon, est-ce que vous comprenez l'anglais?
Non, monsieur, je ne comprends pas l'anglais.
Je comprends un peu le français.
Pardon, est-ce que vous comprenez l'anglais?
Non, monsieur, je ne comprends pas l'anglais.
Je comprends un peu le français.
Now imagine that you're the person sitting next to the French woman.
You want to begin a conversation.
So try asking her if she understands.
Ask her if she understands French.
Est-ce que vous comprenez le français?
Est-ce que vous comprenez le français?
Now ask her if she understands English.
How does she tell you that she doesn't understand English?
How does she ask you if you understand French?
Est-ce que vous comprenez le français?
Est-ce que vous comprenez le français, monsieur?
Tell her you understand a little.
She wants to ask you if you're American.
Est-ce que vous comprenez l'anglais, monsieur?
Est-ce que vous comprenez l'anglais, monsieur?
Answer it using the expression, a little.
Est-ce que vous comprenez le français?
Je comprends un peu le français.
Ask her if she understands French.
Est-ce que vous comprenez le français?
Now, ask her if she understands English.
How does she tell you that she doesn't understand English?
How does she ask you if you understand French?
Est-ce que vous comprenez le français?
Tell her you understand a little.
How does she ask you if you're American?
Est-ce que vous comprenez l'anglais, monsieur?
Answer it using the expression a little.
Est-ce que vous comprenez un peu.
Est-ce que vous comprenez le français?
Je comprends un peu le français.
Now you do understand French a little.
Don't be concerned if you've not made every response correctly.
All that you've learned here will be reviewed in future units.
If you've mastered about 80% of the material in this lesson,
you're ready to move on to the next.
Otherwise, you should invest another 30 minutes in doing this unit over again.
This is the end of today's lesson.
When you continue with the next unit tomorrow,
please begin with track number two.
